questions.text: A 2600gms newborn was born with hypotonicity of the abdominal wall and theere is wrinkled appearance of the skin as shown below. Triad of the syndrome includes all except:
questions.solution:
Prune-Belly Syndrome, also called triad syndrome or Eagle-Barrett syndrome consists of the characteristic Triad:

  • deficient abdominal muscles,
  • undescended testes,
  • and urinary tract abnormalities probably results from severe urethral obstruction in fetal life.
  • Oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia are common complications in the perinatal period.
  • dysplasia of kidneys
  • Malrotation of the bowel
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • musculoskeletal abnormalities

Option A. Café au lait spots are features of Neurofibromatosis.Others are:

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 577, Page- 3281

questions.text: Mother notices this following rash on the baby in his first week of life, she is worried about her child, but pediatrician is not. What could it be?
questions.solution:
Toxic erythema of the newborn (also known as erythema toxicum and erythema toxicum neonatorum) is a benign, self-limited, evanescent eruption, affecting as many as half of all full-term newborn infants but is less common in infants born prematurely. The lesions are firm, yellow-white, 1-2 mm papules or pustules with a surrounding erythematous flare. Lesions may be sparse or numerous and either clustered in several sites or widely dispersed over much of the body surface. The palms and soles are usually spared. Peak incidence occurs on the 2nd day of life, but new lesions may erupt during the first few days as the rash waxes and wanes.

Eosinophils can be demonstrated in Wright-stained smears of the intralesional contents. Cultures are sterile. The cause of erythema toxicum is unknown. The course is brief (3-7 days), and lesions generally resolve without pigmentation. No therapy is required.

Other options:

A. Mongolian spots or Dermal melanocytosis, appears as blue or slate-gray macular lesions, occurs most commonly in the sacral area but may be found over the posterior thighs, legs, back, and shoulders. The spots may be solitary or numerous and often involve large areas. They usually fade during the first few years of life as a result of darkening of the overlying skin. If lesions persist, they may be treated with lasers, if desired. Malignant degeneration does not occur.

C. Neonatal milia are benign and transient subepidermal keratin cysts that present as small firm white papules in various numbers most commonly distributed on the face, but they can also be present on other anatomical areas such as the upper trunk, extremities, and genital area (prepuce). The lesions of congenital milia do not require any particular treatment since these lesions tend to resolve spontaneously.

D. Epstein pearls are usually white or yellowish, and they tend to be 1-2 mm, KERATINOUS cysts, occurring in up to 60-85% of all newborns, located along the mid palatine raphe and near the junction of the hard and soft palate, requires no treatment.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 688, Page- 4042

questions.text: The following test is being done in an unstable 5 years old child with suspected septic shock and its normal value is
questions.solution:
This illustrates how to check capillary refill. CRT is a quick test that measures peripheral perfusion and can be measured on the finger, hand, foot, or chest.

A normal capillary refill time is less than 3 seconds.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 85, Page- 609

questions.text: Which of the following nerve roots are damaged in this child born by instrumental delivery?
questions.solution:
Erb-Duchenne paralysis results from injury to the nerve roots of the 5th and 6th cervical nerves, with the 7th affected in 50% of instances. The infant loses the power to abduct the arm from the shoulder, rotate the arm externally, and supinate the forearm. The characteristic position consists of adduction and internal rotation of the arm with pronation of the forearm. Power to extend the forearm is retained, but the biceps reflex is absent; the Moro reflex is absent on the affected side some sensory impairment. Power in the forearm and hand grasps is preserved unless the lower part of the plexus is also injured; the presence of hand grasp is a favorable prognostic sign.

Other options:

D. Klumpke paralysis is a rare form of brachial palsy in which injury to the 7th and 8th cervical nerves and the 1st thoracic nerve produces a paralyzed hand and ipsilateral ptosis and miosis (Horner syndrome)if the sympathetic fibers of the first thoracic root are also injured.

A. Injuries of C4 root may cause phrenic nerve paralysis and respiratory distress

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 122, Page- 1068

questions.text: What is the radiological sign seen in the following chest x ray?
questions.solution:
Meniscus sign :

If the patient is upright when the X-ray is taken, then fluid will surround the lung base forming a 'meniscus' - a concave line obscuring the costophrenic angle and part or all of the hemidiaphragm

Other options:

A. Sail sign - Thethymic sail sign represents a triangular-shaped inferior margin of the normal thymus seen on a neonatal frontal chest radiograph.

C. Pneumothorax can be seen on a chest X-ray as a dark area around the edge of the lung, or as a collapsed lung.

D. Air bronchogram appears as a branching, dark-colored structure surrounded by a lighter-colored area.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 451, Page- 2654

questions.text: Identify the sign seen in chest x ray:
questions.solution:
Chest Xray reveals mediastinal air, with a more distinct cardiac border than normal. A "spinnaker sail sign" or "angel wing sign" occurs when air deviates the thymus upward and outward, which is seen more often in pediatric pneumomediastinum patients. On the lateral projection, the posterior mediastinal structures are clearly defined, there may be a lucent ring ("ring sign") around the right pulmonary artery, and retrosternal air can usually be seen. Vertical streaks of air in the mediastinum and subcutaneous air are often observed.

Other options:

B. Meniscus sign : If the patient is upright when the X-ray is taken, then fluid will surround the lung base forming a 'meniscus' - a concave line obscuring the costophrenic angle and part or all of the hemidiaphragm

C. Sail sign - Thethymic sail sign represents a triangular-shaped inferior margin of the normal thymus seen on a neonatal frontal chest radiograph.

D. Air bronchogram appears as a branching, dark-colored structure surrounded by a lighter-colored area.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 462, Page- 2707

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in this disorder associated with this typical rash?
questions.solution:
The characteristic heliotrope rash is a blue-violet discoloration of the eyelids that may be associated with periorbital edema in patients with Juvenile Dermatomyositis(JDM). Rash develops as the first symptom and appears concomitant with weakness rarely. Erythema is also commonly seen over the knees and elbows.

Other options:

B. JDM children often exhibit extreme photosensitivity to UV light exposure with generalized erythema in sun-exposed areas. If seen over the chest and neck, this erythema is known as the shawl sign.

C. Gottron papules - bright-pink or pale, shiny, thickened, or atrophic plaques over the metacarpal phalangeal joints, proximal interphalangeal joints, and distal interphalangeal joints and occasionally on the knees, elbows, small joints of the toes, and ankle malleoli

A. Mechanic's hands - a thickened erythematous and scaly rash develops in children over the palms and soles along the flexor tendons

Fig. Findings in Dermatomyositis

a. Gottron papules

e. Heliotrope rash

f. Shawl sign

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 200, Page- 1500

questions.text: Identify the following morphological finding in the given smear:
questions.solution:
Howell-Jolly bodies are small, dark, round, basophilic inclusions in red blood cells (RBCs) that are remnants of the nucleus. They are a sign of splenic dysfunction and can be seen in peripheral blood smears when the spleen is absent or not functioning properly.

Other options:

A. Target cells - red blood cells that have a dark center surrounded by a white ring, and a dark outer ring that contains haemoglobin. Seen in Hemoglobinopathies, Iron deficiency anemia, Liver disease, xerocytosis

C. Bite cells - abnormally shaped red blood cells that have one or more semicircular portions removed from their margin, giving them a bitten-out appearance. Associated with hemolytic anemia and Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.

D. Burr cells, also known as echinocytes - red blood cells with an abnormal membrane that has many small, evenly spaced thorny projections. Seen in uremia, Liver disease, Vitamin E deficiency, Pyruvate kinase deficiency, DIC, HUS, TTP

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 496, Page- 2930

questions.text: A 2 yrs old male child presents to pediatric emergency department with a history of fever x 2 wks. He has received multiple antibiotics. Blood tests for Typhoid, Malaria, Dengue are all negative. He however had sterile pyuria in one of the reports (urine C/s - sterile). BCG scar is indurated and H/o conjunctivitis, cheilitis and erythematous rash over body for initial 5 days of illness is observed. The most likely treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
All this signs and symptoms points to the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.


Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 208, Page- 1547

questions.text: A 9 year old boy presented to OPD with recurrent joint pain and requirement of transfusion since last 8 years, what is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of Hemophilia such as easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, and hemarthroses, begin when the child starts to cruise. Although bleeding may occur in any area of the body, the hallmark of hemophilic bleeding is Hemarthrosis.

Bleeding into the joints may be induced by minor trauma; many hemarthroses are spontaneous. The earliest joint hemorrhages appear most often in the ankle. In the older child and adolescent, hemarthroses of the knees and elbows are also common.

Repeated bleeding episodes into the same joint in a patient with severe hemophilia may result in a "target" joint.

Other options:

A. ITP is an acute condition that can present with a variety of symptoms, including bruising, bleeding, petechiae, purpura and ecchymoses.

C. Thalassemia usually presents with anemia and bone deformities

D. Fanconi anemia presents with a number of physical abnormalities, bone marrow failure, and an increased risk of cancer.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 525, Page- 3029

questions.text: Identify the lower limb deformity.
questions.solution: Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 715, Page- 4210

questions.text: The findings are associated with which of the following syndrome?
questions.solution:
This newborn shows a webbed neck with low hairline, shield chest with widespread nipples, abnormal ears, and micrognathia. The newborn in second picture also has prominent lymphedema of the hands and feet. All points to Turner Syndrome.

Other options:

A. Marfan syndrome - caused by a mutation in the FBN1 gene, which is responsible for producing fibrillin, a protein that helps to form elastic fibers in connective tissue. People with Marfan syndrome are often tall and thin, with long limbs, fingers, toes, and arms. They may also have flexible joints and a curved spine.

B. Klinefelter syndrome - affects males and is caused by an extra X chromosome, presenting as tall stature, small testes, gynecomastia, and azoospermia

D. Down syndrome - occurs when a person has an extra copy of chromosome 21. It causes a distinct facial appearance, intellectual disability, and developmental delays

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 99, Page 771

questions.text: Based on karyotype shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
(47, XXY) Karyotype

Clinical features seen in Klinefelter syndrome include:

  • Tall stature with long extremities
  • Small penis size and Atrophy of the testicles
  • Infertility due to azoospermia
  • Reduced facial hair
  • Gynecomastia
  • Osteoporosis
  • Decreased intelligence
  • Learning disability and Behavioral problems

Other options:

A. Williams syndrome - caused by a deletion of genes on chromosome 7 and characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, with distinctive facial features

B. Down syndrome - occurs when a person has an extra copy of chromosome 21. It causes a distinct facial appearance, intellectual disability, and developmental delays

C. Fragile X syndrome - caused by a mutation in the X-linked FMR1 gene and is the most common cause of inherited mental retardation

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 99, Page 771

questions.text: Identify the eye change shown in the given picture -
questions.solution:
Bitot's spots are dry, foamy patches of conjunctiva caused by vitamin A deficiency.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 66, Page 454

questions.text: What is the name of sign depicted in the following image?
questions.solution:
Brudzinski sign and Kernig signs are bedside signs of meningism(meningeal irritation).



Fig. Babinski reflex

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 643, Page- 3762
